Award.AbstractNarration:
Proposal: 1403860/1403053
PI: Rege/Hayes
Institution: Arizona State University/ Montana State
Title: Polypeptide-Templated Nanoparticles as Colorimetric Sensors of Ionizing Radiation

Ionizing radiation, including X-rays and gamma rays, is useful in several medical, defense, space, and agricultural applications. However, uncontrolled ionizing radiation can lead to large scale disasters and damage to human health. Given the necessity to balance potential deleterious effects and widespread application, it is important to develop novel radiation-sensing methods in order to ensure safety and prevent accidents. We have recently developed a novel nanobiosensing approach in which we employed proteins for templating the formation of metal nanoparticles from colorless metal salts. This change from colorless metal salts to colored dispersions of nanoparticles in water is a simple and visual indicator of ionizing radiation. In the proposed research, we will carry out a fundamental study on how different amino acids and small peptides mediate nanoparticle formation in the presence of different doses of ionizing radiation. Both, experimental and mathematical modeling approaches will be employed to study this behavior.

Our preliminary results indicated that polypeptides are capable of templating plasmonic metal nanoparticles from colorless metal salts in presence of ionizing radiation (X-Rays). In the proposed research, we will carry out an extensive investigation into how each of the 20 natural amino acids template bimetallic gold-silver nanoparticles upon exposure to different doses of ionizing radiation. We will then investigate dipeptides (?minimal peptides?), in which an amino acid with activity for templating the formation of plasmonic nanoparticles is juxtaposed with an amino acid that can bind and stabilize the templated nanoparticles. In addition, pentapeptides in which the binding and templating amino acids are separated by a tri-glycine linker will also be investigated. Mathematical modeling will be employed in order to investigate how different amino acids and peptides, together with experimental physicochemical conditions influence the formation kinetics of bimetallic nanoparticles. Water radiolysis, metal ion reduction, and nanoparticle formation will be modeled, and effects of pH, scavenging agents, and templating biomolecules will be investigated. Experimental and modeling studies will be employed for molecular engineering and developing sequence-property relationships for polypeptide-based colorimetric nanobiosensors for ionizing radiation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF 1403860: Project Outcomes

 

Background and Significance. Ionizing radiation, including X-rays, has several applications in nuclear power, astrophysics, decontamination, and medical imaging and therapy. However, errors in application and delivery of ionizing radiation can lead to deleterious consequences. Rapid and accurate detection of ionizing radiation doses is therefore critical in applications related to security and human health. Currently available detection approaches are cumbersome to operate, require long processing times, demonstrate non-linear responses, are expensive to fabricate, require sophisticated processing methods and / or measure only point doses. There is a critical need for fundamental studies that can lead to new approaches for rapidly sensing ionizing radiation in an easily detectable, quantifiable, and robust manner. In this project, our goal was to carry out fundamental studies in nanotechnology and biotechnology leading to colorimetric nano-bio sensors for ionizing radiation.

 

Intellectual Merit. We developed a novel platform in which ionizing radiation (X-rays) was employed for templating the formation of visibly colored dispersions of gold nanoparticles from initially colorless gold salts. The color change was because of the optical properties of the gold nanoparticles formed in response to the radiation and was easy to visualize. The intensity of the color formed was dependent on the dose of radiation delivered, which facilitated quantification and prediction of unknown doses using cost-efficient absorbance spectroscopy. This approach was interfaced with biocompatible gels in order to facilitate easy handling with these gel nanosensors. As part of collaborative research, we developed a mathematical model to enhance our understanding of the nanoparticle formation process in response to ionizing radiation. We extended findings on photons or X-rays and demonstrated the utility of this approach for quantifying doses of other forms of ionizing radiation including protons, electrons and brachytherapy sources. Further fundamental insights led to a new system for detecting dose distribution in a spatial manner. Our studies also led to investigations on the efficacy of templating molecules, including surfactants and amino acids, and proteins, leading to an improved understanding of how molecular structure and properties influence detection of ionizing radiation in these systems. We evaluated the efficacy of these systems in well plates, anthropomorphic phantoms used in clinical planning for radiotherapy, and also in canine patients undergoing radiotherapy. We also surveyed the field of molecular and nanoscale detectors of ionizing radiation, and disseminated these as a published resource for other scientists. Our studies have resulted in novel fundamental advances with a strong potential for translation of these technologies for use in several application areas. 

 

Broader Impacts. We have developed an entirely new approach to detecting different forms of ionizing radiation and anticipate that these fundamental studies and related translation will find application in several fields including human health (e.g. radiotherapy), agriculture, and security. Our findings from these studies  have been highlighted in general and technical news outlets as well as by scientific journals, which are further indicators of the novelty and impact of our work. Students contributing to these research projects were trained at the interface of engineering, nanotechnology, biotechnology, and radiation physics and chemistry. Collaborations on mathematical modeling and highly productive interactions with radiation physicists and clinicians further led to an enriched training and educational experience. Students mentored on this project have won several national and local awards. Foundational aspects of this project have been integrated into the formal coursework at ASU including in Nanobiotechnology, which is a course taught to both undergraduate and graduate students by the PI. Overall, this project has greatly enhanced the technical training and education of students, which will lead to a life-long impact as they pursue their careers in STEM fields.
